title: Prof. Dr. Felix Schönbrodt
text:
Managing Director of OSC
Faculty of Psychology



Felix.Schoenbrodt@psy.lmu.de



Personal Website



Faculty Website



Department of Psychology



















Mission Statement
HELLO THERE. I am principal investigator for Psychological Methods and Assessment at the Department of Psychology. The reproducibility of research findings is a core criterion of science, which however, has been challenged by the failure of recent large-scale replication projects.

Together with the board of the German Psychological Society (DGPs) I developed the society's recommendations for data sharing in psychology.



Research Interests

Open Science
Psychology
Psychological Methods
Data Sharing

Selected Publications


2024

"Machine Learning Applications in Organizational Behavior"
Smith, J., Johnson, A., & Williams, R.

Journal of Applied Research, 42(3), 256-278




 DOI





2023

"Open Methods in Psychology"
Schönbrodt, F.

Psychological Methods, 15(2), 112-143




 DOI

title: Benedikt Ehrenwirth
text:
BSc Student
Faculty of Psychology & Education



B.Ehrenwirth@campus.lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am firmly convinced that the shift towards a research culture where Open Science is the norm is not solely driven by changes in researchers' attitudes but also by a growing confidence in the feasibility of open research practices.The courses of my Bachelor's program in psychology at LMU have highlighted the catalysing role of various technical tools and digital platforms in Open Science. Although initially perceived as potentially demanding extra effort, tools such as R and R Markdown can in fact streamline our work and are surprisingly easy to learn.Thus I find it important that promoting Open Science includes highlighting these practical advantages of technical solutions for researchers' lives. This is why I am involved in the RPsyche course, which strives to teach fellow students how R can be used for research so that both themselves and others benefit from it.

title: Alp Kaan Aksu
text:
BSc Student
Faculty of Psychology & Education



os@alpkaanaksu.com



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am currently studying psychology at the LMU and computer science at TUM. Even before I started studying psychology, I had a lot of questions related to good scientific practice, and few weeks into my first psychology semester at the LMU, I learned about the Open Science movement (thanks to the ReproducibiliTea Journal Club!). I think it is very valuable to learn more about Open Science, to talk about it with others, to come up with new questions and to try to find answers together. This is why I joined the ReproducibiliTea Journal Club. I am now part of the organisation team of this Journal Club as I think it is one of the best places to start raising awareness about Open Science and spreading good scientific practice among students, since mostly bachelor's and master's students attend our meetings. On a related note, I am also interested in science communication and how we can make scientific knowledge accesible to everyone.

title: Maximilian Frank
text:
PhD Candidate
Faculty of Psychology & Education



maximilian.frank@psy.lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
My name is Maximilian Frank and I am a doctoral candidate at the Ludwig-Maximilians-University of Munich in the DFG priority program "META-REP" and conduct research on heterogeneity estimations in meta-analyses. Back the time of my psychology studies, I was lucky to be assigned to emprical course (EmPra) in which we conducted a replication of an existing study. This was my first point of contact with the topic replication crisis and the many proposals for reforming science that can be summarized under the term "Open Science". Since then, the topic has stuck with me and I have consequently become involved in several Open Science initiatives. Personally, in addition to a transparent and reproducible work process in my own research, I am engaged in teaching Open Science practices to students and early career researchers. They are the scientists of the future, which is why we owe them a state-of-the-art education which covers these important topics to benefit science as a whole.

title: Staff
text:
Developer and Research Support




  





  


  







Pat Callahan



MSc


Medicine




Read More!






Scientific Coordinator of the OSC




  





  


  


  


  







Malika Ihle



Dr.


Open Science Center



Malika Ihle is the LMU Open Science Center Coordinator, supporting the scientific board in developing a comprehensive approach to open research that extends across all disciplines, using both bottom-up and top-down strategies. Her role is to provide peer-to-peer training and develop an open research curriculum, coordinate grassroots initiatives and organise various events such as seminars and conferences, support meta-research collaborations, liaise with local, national (e.g. the German Reproducibility Network (GRN)), and international stakeholders to inform the design of incentives and policies, and co-develop a strategic plan to make the LMU Open Science Center a sustainable entity.

Read More!

title: LMU Open Science Summer School 2025
text:
Philologicum Library, Ludwigstraße 25, 80539 Munich 
          
        
        
    
    
        
            📅 Date & Time
            15 -19 September, 202514:00 - 17:00 CET
        
        
            🌐 Language
            English(German Q&A available)
        
        
            💻 Format
            Hybrid EventIn-person & Online
        
    
    
        Register
    




Overview
The LMU Open Science Center (OSC) is excited to announce the call for applications for its 5th hybrid summer school (OSSS25): deadline July 14!
This year’s iteration has two tracks to provide participants with two sets of skills. You are invited to apply for one or both tracks. For either track, you can choose to participate either online or in-person.
Track 1: Open Science knowledge and skills
In this track, early career researchers who are Open Science novices learn to make their research more transparent, reproducible and credible in the eyes of their peers, the public, and funding agencies. This track consists of public lectures accessible to anyone as well as hands-on practical workshops for selected applicants and extends from Monday 15.09.2025 9:00 to Friday 19.09.2025 14:30.
Participants of this track learn how to:

Specify research design and set up statistical plans in advance of collecting data to prevent biases in analyses, with the help of preregistration and data simulation.
Create computationally reproducible workflows to be more efficient and spot mistakes in data wrangling or analyses, through programming with version controlled scripts.
Prepare and share data and code in connection with manuscripts by applying the Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable principles, and using adequate repositories and licenses to accumulate credit and citations.

Track 2: Open Science instructor training
In this track, early career researchers or research support staff interested in becoming Open Science instructors develop essential pedagogical skills to promote Open Science through teaching - no prior experience in teaching required. This track extends from Friday 19.09.2025 14:30 to 17:30.
Participants of this track learn how to:

Design and deliver Open Science workshops, and apply basic didactic techniques to diverse audiences.
Apply activation methods in the classroom to foster motivation and attention.
Develop skills to advocate for Open Science, to lead research groups and discussions around Open Science, and to analyse the potential challenges and issues around the implementation of Open Science practices.

After joining this track, you will have the opportunity to put your new skills into practice and co-deliver a workshop at LMU to become a certified Open Science instructor.


Keynote presenters


Laura Meier
Maximilian Frank
Florian Kohrt




Questions?
We are looking forward to your participation! For any questions, please contact us at osc@lmu.de

title: Management
text:
Managing Director of OSC




  





  


  


  


  







Felix Schönbrodt



Prof. Dr.


Psychology



Professor at the Department of Psychology, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Germany. Managing director of the LMU Open Science Center and board member of the META-REP priority program (‘A meta-scientific research program to analyse and optimise replicability in the behavioral, social, and cognitive Sciences’). Interested in Open Science, Metascience, implicit motives, machine learning, responsible research assessment (CoARA), solarpunk, piano, and cooking.

Read More!






Scientific Coordinator of the OSC




  





  


  


  


  







Malika Ihle



Dr.


Open Science Center



Malika Ihle is the LMU Open Science Center Coordinator, supporting the scientific board in developing a comprehensive approach to open research that extends across all disciplines, using both bottom-up and top-down strategies. Her role is to provide peer-to-peer training and develop an open research curriculum, coordinate grassroots initiatives and organise various events such as seminars and conferences, support meta-research collaborations, liaise with local, national (e.g. the German Reproducibility Network (GRN)), and international stakeholders to inform the design of incentives and policies, and co-develop a strategic plan to make the LMU Open Science Center a sustainable entity.

Read More!

title: Giacomo De Nicola
text:
PhD Candidate
Faculty of Math, Informatics & Stats



giacomo.denicola@stat.uni-muenchen.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am a Research Associate and Doctoral Candidate at the Department of Statistics, and part of the Chair of Applied Statistics in Social Sciences, Economics and Business. I am also an active member of the COVID-19 Data Analysis Group (CODAG) at the LMU.

I believe that making science more transparent and open to the public is of paramount importance to maintain its credibility and increase its weight in public decision making. For this reason, I think science should invest more in effective communication. I am also an advocate for more data literacy within the general population, which I think will be needed to effectively challenge present and future societal challenges.

title: Franka Etzel
text:
MSc Student
Faculty of Psychology & Education



franka.etzel@campus.lmu.de










Mission Statement
I´m a psychology student at the LMU and the topic of Open Science has stuck with me ever since I heard about it for the first time in our statistics course. Especially through my job as a student assistant at the Chair of Psychological Methods and Diagnostics I learned more about Open Science and good scientific practice not only in theory. It started becoming more and more important to me so that I recently joined the organisational team of the Journal Club "ReproducibiliTea". To me it´s very important to further deepen my knowledge about Open Science and good scientific practices so I can spread the ideas and discuss different aspects of Open Science with others.

title: Dr. Malika Ihle
text:
Scientific Coordinator of the OSC
Department of Open Science Center



malika.ihle@psy.lmu.de



Personal Website



LMU Official Website



















Mission Statement
Malika Ihle is the LMU Open Science Center Coordinator, supporting the scientific board in developing a comprehensive approach to open research that extends across all disciplines, using both bottom-up and top-down strategies. Her role is to provide peer-to-peer training and develop an open research curriculum, coordinate grassroots initiatives and organise various events such as seminars and conferences, support meta-research collaborations, liaise with local, national (e.g. the German Reproducibility Network (GRN)), and international stakeholders to inform the design of incentives and policies, and co-develop a strategic plan to make the LMU Open Science Center a sustainable entity.



Research Interests

Open Science
Psychology
Psychological Methods
Data Sharing

title: Pat Callahan
text:
Developer and Research Support
Faculty of Medicine



Patrick.callahan@campus.lmu.de













Mission Statement
I am a MSc student in Epidemiology at the Institute for Medical Information Processing, Biometry, and Epidemiology (IBE). My interests lie particularly in improving scientific reproducibility by teaching software development practices, and in creating data analysis tools which can be used to assess replicability of research findings. I believe treating scientific analyses as if they were software development projects helps facilitate standard, understandable frameworks which can play a large role in addressing issues of reproducibility and replicability of research findings.
